Title: The Dangers of Knowledge ï½œ Tao Te Ching Chapter 65 Explained

Content.Knowledge Point: The ancient masters understood the Tao and made people forget, not educate.
Content.Text: The ancient masters who understood the way of the Tao did not educate people, but made them forget.

Content.Knowledge Point: Smart people are difficult to guide because they think they are too clever.
Content.Text: Smart people are difficult to guide because they think they are too clever.

Content.Knowledge Point: Using cleverness to rule a country leads to ruin, while avoiding it leads to prosperity.
Content.Text: To use cleverness to rule a country is to lead the country to ruin. To avoid cleverness in ruling a country is to lead the country to prosperity.

Content.Knowledge Point: Knowing the alternatives between ignorance and knowledge is a pattern, and remaining aware of it is a virtue.
Content.Text: Knowing the two alternatives is a pattern. Remaining aware of the pattern is a virtue.

Content.Knowledge Point: This dark and mysterious virtue is profound and leads to harmony with the heavens.
Content.Text: This dark and mysterious virtue is profound. It is opposite our natural inclination, but leads to harmony with the heavens.

Content.Knowledge Point: The chapter's ideas may seem odd to those raised in Western culture, especially regarding democracy.
Content.Text: This chapter seems a little bit odd, especially to those of us who were raised in Western culture, on ideas of democracy and the power of individuals in government.

Content.Knowledge Point: Lao Tzu's views on rulers and subjects' ignorance may not align with modern democratic values.
Content.Text: Is Lao Tzu indicating that rulers should keep their subjects intentionally ignorant so that they cannot interfere in politics? It does kind of seem to read that way.

Content.Knowledge Point: Lao Tzu's views may have been influenced by his lack of exposure to democratic systems.
Content.Text: I think it is fair to acknowledge that the idea of democracy is a very important part of the culture. I think it is fair to acknowledge that Lao Tzu probably never had any contact with any sort of democratic system of government before.

Content.Knowledge Point: The benefits and drawbacks of knowledge are complex, as demonstrated by Fritz Haber's story.
Content.Text: Probably one of the biggest issues with knowledge is that it is not always the same. It often leads to pride and self-righteousness. When we think that we know a good deal about things, we often try to play God with them. And this can lead to terrible results.

Content.Knowledge Point: Fritz Haber's invention of nitrogen fertilizers had both positive and negative consequences.
Content.Text: You should go and watch this video if you have some free time, because I think it's really worth taking a look at. Haber was prompted towards this invention by a panic caused by the realization that global population growth was beginning to outstrip the government. It's probably that this invention prevented an incalculably disastrous human crisis. In fact, it's estimated that around half of all people alive today simply could not have been if nitrogen fertilizers had never been invented.

Content.Knowledge Point: Fritz Haber later invented chemical weapons with devastating consequences.
Content.Text: However, the story isn't all that black and white, because Fritz Haber later brought forth another invention that had a dramatic impact on humanity. Chlorine, phosphine, and mustard gas. If you know even a little bit about World War I, you'll know that being exposed to these kinds of gases was one of the most horrific things a soldier could experience in battle.

Content.Knowledge Point: Fritz Haber justified the use of chemical weapons, but they ultimately caused more harm than good.
Content.Text: Chlorine gas damages the air tract, causing buildup of fluid in the lungs, and eventually can cause a person to basically drown on dry land. Mustard gas causes severe chemical burns wherever it touches skin or tissue. Both are terrible ways to die. Haber justified the research and use of chemical weapons because he claimed that the quick and decisive victory they would ensure would in the long term save thousands of lives. However, he was wrong. Chemical weapons were used by both sides and did not prove decisive for either.

Content.Knowledge Point: Chemical weapons have been used more recently in various conflicts, causing harm to civilians.
Content.Text: Incredibly, these chemical weapons have even been used more recently in Yemen, Iraq, Iran, and Syria, often against civilians.

Content.Knowledge Point: Fritz Haber's invention of a pesticide gas variant was later used in the Holocaust.
Content.Text: Unfortunately, this is one of those genies that never really gets back into the bottle. The tragedy doesn't even end there, however, because the Nazis later used a variant of pesticide gas invented by Haber to exterminate millions of Jews during the Holocaust. Fritz Haber was himself a Jew.

Content.Knowledge Point: Knowledge is a double-edged sword, as demonstrated by Fritz Haber's story.
Content.Text: Now, breaking this all down, I think we need to be careful about making judgments about people who we have never met and who lived under circumstances we never experienced. But I think this sobering story can serve as a pretty stark warning about how knowledge is a bit of a two-edged sword.

Content.Knowledge Point: Knowledge should be paired with intuition and closeness to Dao to avoid negative consequences.
Content.Text: We shouldn't assume that greater knowledge always leads to greater outcomes. Knowledge is dangerous if it's not paired with intuition and a closeness with Dao.

Content.Knowledge Point: Nitrogen fertilizers have both positive and negative impacts on the environment.
Content.Text: You know how Fritz Haber invented those fertilizers that saved all those people? Well, even this invention isn't without downsides. I personally used to live within miles of a lake where these kinds of fertilizers leaked over time and nearly destroyed an entire ecosystem. Fertilizers may allow vastly increased production of food, but they can also have really terrible impacts on the environment.

Content.Knowledge Point: The benefits and drawbacks of knowledge are complex, and there may not be a clear answer.
Content.Text: Is it worth it? I certainly don't think I'm in a place to make a judgment like that. What I'm trying to show here is that these things are often not all that black and white.

Content.Knowledge Point: The best approach is to stay close to intuition and make informed decisions.
Content.Text: Now, to bring this all back to the chapter, I guess I really don't have a conclusion to give you guys about it. I think I'd rather have you form your own opinion here. Is it better for a people to be educated or kept in ignorance? Knowledge certainly has a lot of dangers. However, on the other hand, despotic governments are often able to do what they do largely by keeping their subjects in ignorance. Maybe the benefits of knowledge outweigh the cost. What I'm really trying to do here is give you guys some food for thought and to impress upon you that there are costs for ignorance as well as costs for knowledge. Everything comes at a cost. Maybe there is no right answer. Maybe there is a lesser of two evils. You're gonna have to decide that for yourself.

Content.Knowledge Point: The best approach is to stay close to intuition and make informed decisions.
Content.Text: At the end of the day, I think the best thing we can do is to stay close to intuition, so that we can be guided on how to use and how not to use knowledge in our own personal lives.
